meanings.def: a regular rise and fall in the level of the sea, caused by the pull of the moon and sun; the flow of water that happens as the sea rises and falls
examples: the ebb and flow of the tide
The tide is in/out.
Is the tide coming in or going out?
The body was washed up on the beach by the tide.
We'll swim back to the beach before the tide turns.
Short-term loans are designed to tide borrowers over until their next payday.
She tied her hair up with ribbon.
We have to get up early to catch the tide.
We went out to sea on the ebb tide.
the time of day when the highest tides occur

meanings.def: the direction in which the opinion of a large number of people seems to be moving
examples: It takes courage to speak out against the tide of opinion.
There is a growing tide of opposition to the idea.
a tide of optimism
He didn't have the courage to swim against the political tide.
In the early 1990s there was a marked turn of the tide.
Seeing the tide was now running in his direction, he renewed his campaign for reform.
the shifting tides of history

meanings.def: a large amount of something unpleasant that is increasing and is difficult to control
examples: There is anxiety about the rising tide of crime.
Measures have been taken to stem the tide of pornography (= stop it from getting worse).

meanings.def: a feeling that you suddenly have that gets stronger and stronger
examples: A tide of rage surged through her.
They were carried along on a tide of euphoria.

meanings.def: a time or season of the year
examples: Christmastide

meanings.def: to agree with/oppose the attitudes or opinions that most other people have
used to say that there is a change in somebody’s luck or in how successful they are being
examples: The tide turned for the Canadian at the start of the second set.
This contract is probably our last chance to turn the tide.

idioms.idiom: go, swim, etc. with/against the tide
idioms.def: to agree with/oppose the attitudes or opinions that most other people have

idioms.idiom: the tide turned | turn the tide
idioms.def: used to say that there is a change in somebody’s luck or in how successful they are being
examples: The tide turned for the Canadian at the start of the second set.
